articles.headline: Biden signs infrastructure bill, promoting benefits for Americans.
articles.snippet: Billions of dollars will now pour into American communities, although the final package falls short of the president’s ambitions.
articles.abstract: Billions of dollars will now pour into American communities, although the final package falls short of the president’s ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed a $1 trillion infrastructure bill into law on Monday afternoon, a bipartisan victory that will pour billions into the nation’s roads, ports and power lines.

articles.headline: How a Dispute Over Groceries Led to Artillery Strikes in Ukraine
articles.snippet: In a sign of volatile East-West relations, a dispute over shopping in the Ukrainian conflict zone spiraled into fighting that sent war jitters rippling through Europe and the U.S.
articles.abstract: In a sign of volatile East-West relations, a dispute over shopping in the Ukrainian conflict zone spiraled into fighting that sent war jitters rippling through Europe and the U.S.

articles.headline: Alex Jones Loses by Default in Remaining Sandy Hook Defamation Suits
articles.snippet: A Connecticut judge’s ruling against the Infowars host combines with decisions in Texas to grant a clean sweep for the families of 10 shooting victims.
articles.abstract: A Connecticut judge’s ruling against the Infowars host combines with decisions in Texas to grant a clean sweep for the families of 10 shooting victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A state court in Connecticut granted a sweeping victory to the families of eight people killed in a 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., who had sued the far-right broadcaster and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and his Infowars media outlet for defamation.

articles.headline: Europe Toughens Rules for Unvaccinated as Fourth Covid Wave Swells
articles.snippet: Austria took the hardest line yet on Monday, beginning a lockdown aimed exclusively at those who are not inoculated, part of a pattern to make life harder for resisters.
articles.abstract: Austria took the hardest line yet on Monday, beginning a lockdown aimed exclusively at those who are not inoculated, part of a pattern to make life harder for resisters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — As temperatures drop and coronavirus infections spike across Europe, some countries are introducing increasingly targeted restrictions against the unvaccinated who are driving another wave of contagion and putting economic recoveries, public health and an eventual return to prepandemic freedoms at risk.

articles.headline: With Halo Infinite, Microsoft Hopes to Rekindle Its Flagship Game
articles.snippet: Though interest in Halo has waned over the years, the company is banking on a new version to goose sales of its Xbox and subscription gaming service.
articles.abstract: Though interest in Halo has waned over the years, the company is banking on a new version to goose sales of its Xbox and subscription gaming service.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft released its first Xbox console 20 years ago, executives did not think that Halo, a new game set in a 26th-century galactic war pitting humans against alien invaders, would become the face of the tech giant’s gaming aspirations.

articles.headline: Biden’s reliance on I.R.S. enforcement to pay for $1.85 trillion bill hits a snag.
articles.snippet: The head of the Congressional Budget Office said on Monday that beefed-up tax enforcement would raise far less money than the White House projected.
articles.abstract: The head of the Congressional Budget Office said on Monday that beefed-up tax enforcement would raise far less money than the White House projected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pledge to fully pay for his $1.85 trillion social policy and climate spending package depends in large part on having a beefed-up Internal Revenue Service crack down on tax evaders, which the White House says will raise hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue.

articles.headline: The Worst of Both Worlds: Zooming From the Office
articles.snippet: Work life for many is in a mushy middle ground, and what’s at stake isn’t just who is getting talked over in meetings. It’s whether flexibility is sustainable, even with all the benefits it confers.
articles.abstract: Work life for many is in a mushy middle ground, and what’s at stake isn’t just who is getting talked over in meetings. It’s whether flexibility is sustainable, even with all the benefits it confers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, the putt-putt course sat unused. The beanbag chairs lay empty. The kitchen whiteboard, above where the keg used to live, displayed in fading marker “Beers on Tap” from a happy hour in March 2020.

articles.headline: Racial Equity in Infrastructure, a U.S. Goal, Is Left to States
articles.snippet: The decision about how to spend the money falls largely to state governments, raising questions about whether the package can live up to its ambition.
articles.abstract: The decision about how to spend the money falls largely to state governments, raising questions about whether the package can live up to its ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s $1 trillion plan to rebuild America’s infrastructure comes with a built-in promise: No longer will roads, bridges and railways be instruments of bias or racism. Communities that ended up divided along racial lines will be made whole.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: Will an Island in Indonesia Become a New Frontier in the Space Race?
articles.snippet: An Indigenous clan fears it will lose its place in the world as the government pursues a quest to open a spaceport and lure the billionaire SpaceX founder Elon Musk.
articles.abstract: An Indigenous clan fears it will lose its place in the world as the government pursues a quest to open a spaceport and lure the billionaire SpaceX founder Elon Musk.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIAK, Indonesia — For 15 generations, members of the Abrauw clan have lived much like their ancestors. They farm with wooden plows in patches of the rainforest, gather medicinal plants and set traps to catch snakes and wild boar.
articles.byline: By Dera Menra Sijabat, Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti

articles.headline: U.S.-China Summit Produces Little More Than Polite Words, but They Help
articles.snippet: In a chilly relationship of mutual mistrust, staving off the prospect of a broader conflict between two superpowers counts as progress.
articles.abstract: In a chilly relationship of mutual mistrust, staving off the prospect of a broader conflict between two superpowers counts as progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: The virtual meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, produced no breakthroughs in a relationship that has spiraled dangerously downward. That was not the intent.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Cold and Marooned in a Police State as Desperation Takes Hold
articles.snippet: Almost a dozen migrants have died in recent weeks in the standoff between Belarus, a close ally of Russia, and Poland, a member of NATO and the European Union, each determined not to bend.
articles.abstract: Almost a dozen migrants have died in recent weeks in the standoff between Belarus, a close ally of Russia, and Poland, a member of NATO and the European Union, each determined not to bend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the migrant crisis at the Belarus-Poland border.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Uneasy About the Economy, Americans Are Spending Anyway
articles.snippet: Retail sales jumped 1.7 percent in October, the third monthly increase, a rise that highlighted the resilience of the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: Retail sales jumped 1.7 percent in October, the third monthly increase, a rise that highlighted the resilience of the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers are dour about the economy, worried about inflation and pessimistic about the direction of the country in general.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Sapna Maheshwari and Coral Murphy Marcos
